info.sentence: git is a system for creating and updating a distributed source code control repository.
Small batches are more satisfying to the developers, because they get to see their software being used soon after they write it.
Small batches of work make testing easier.
Small batches of work make testing easier.
Small batches make it easier to find a bug when you have one.
Small batches make it easier to find a bug when you have one.
In older models of software development, it was thought that rapid delivery of software to users meant buggy systems that crashed a lot.
There are a variety of version control systems in existence, such as RCS, SCCS, Suberversion, CVS, and git.
git is a system for creating and updating a distributed source code control repository.
Small batches enable rapid feedback from the users on whether the software is delivering what they want.
First things first: don't confuse git with GitHub!
In older models of software development, it was thought that rapid delivery of software to users meant buggy systems that crashed a lot.

Completing and delivering small batches of work at a time is such an important part of DevOps that we could almost say that every other part of DevOps exists to enable frequent, reliable delivery of small improvements to a piece of software.

To complete this section, please read Iterative and incremental development Lesson 2: Version control everythingVersion control is the name for tools that allow the storing of different versions of project files, and the ability to revert to an earlier version (for instance, when a bug is found in the new version).
For the rest of lesson 2, please read: Version control everything Lesson 3: git and GitHubA brief tutorial on using git.

To complete this section, please read Iterative and incremental development Lesson 2: Version control everythingVersion control is the name for tools that allow the storing of different versions of project files, and the ability to revert to an earlier version (for instance, when a bug is found in the new version).
It includes features for adding new files, updating files, deleting files or versions from the repository, branching, resolving version conflicts, and reverting to earlier versions.

Completing and delivering small batches of work at a time is such an important part of DevOps that we could almost say that every other part of DevOps exists to enable frequent, reliable delivery of small improvements to a piece of software.
There are a variety of version control systems in existence, such as RCS, SCCS, Suberversion, CVS, and git.
Small batches are more satisfying to the developers, because they get to see their software being used soon after they write it.
It includes features for adding new files, updating files, deleting files or versions from the repository, branching, resolving version conflicts, and reverting to earlier versions.
Incremental Development"Deliver software frequently..." -- The Agile Manifesto Lesson 1: Why incremental?
GitHub, on the other hand, is a web site that allows for free storage of public repositories ("repos" for short).
Small batches enable rapid feedback from the users on whether the software is delivering what they want.
Small batches allow us to deliver value to the user more rapidly.
Small batches are more satisfying to the developers, because they get to see their software being used soon after they write it.
In older models of software development, it was thought that rapid delivery of software to users meant buggy systems that crashed a lot.
First things first: don't confuse git with GitHub!

It is not necessary to use GitHub in order to use git: some companies have a "origin" repo they keep internally, while other people use other public sites, such as BitBucket, to hold the origin version of their repo.

git is a system for creating and updating a distributed source code control repository.
Small batches are more satisfying to the developers, because they get to see their software being used soon after they write it.
It includes features for adding new files, updating files, deleting files or versions from the repository, branching, resolving version conflicts, and reverting to earlier versions.
GitHub, on the other hand, is a web site that allows for free storage of public repositories ("repos" for short).

It is not necessary to use GitHub in order to use git: some companies have a "origin" repo they keep internally, while other people use other public sites, such as BitBucket, to hold the origin version of their repo.
